title: California Lawmakers Remove LCFS Price Cap from Bill Proposal - ClearBlue Markets
description:
The removal of the price cap language eliminates the most contentious component, easing state legislative risks for the LCFS market.
Still, the program amendments and changes to SB 237, along with recent action at the federal level, point to tightening balances and higher LCFS credit prices.
This dynamic could help absorb excess supply from California and soften the impact of the delayed implementation date of the California LCFS rulemaking from 2024.
This initiative, aimed at improving supply chain efficiency and reducing production costs, may help stabilize gasoline prices and encourage greater supply.
SB 237 is scheduled for a hearing on 16 July in the Assembly Committee on Utilities and Energy.
text:
On July 10, California lawmakers amended proposed bill SB 237 to strike a controversial provision that would have capped LCFS credit prices at their January 2025 average, estimated at around USD 70 to 75 per metric ton. Sponsored by moderate Democrats and backed by Senate leadership, the bill is broadly framed as a gasoline affordability measure. The removal of the price cap language eliminates the most contentious component, easing state legislative risks for the LCFS market.

This follows news in late June that the LCFS amendments to tighten the balances in the program, adopted in November 2024, were finally approved with a 1 July implementation date. The 1 July implementation date was disappointing for those market participants hoping the stricter Carbon Intensity standards would take effect earlier in 2025 and prevent the market from adding to the oversupply. Still, the program amendments and changes to SB 237, along with recent action at the federal level, point to tightening balances and higher LCFS credit prices.

Market reaction is expected to be bullish. LCFS credit prices, currently trading near USD 48 per tonne, are now expected to firm as participants reprice the reduced likelihood of a structural credit suppression. The proposed price cap had raised strong concerns across the clean fuels sector, particularly for emerging segments like sustainable aviation fuel and heavy-duty electrification. These segments already operate with weaker support from complementary policies such as the RFS and WCI and rely heavily on LCFS credit value to support project economics.

Structural Shift and Federal Incentives

Market attention is expected to drift to deeper federal structural shifts, including the potential impacts of the One Big Beautiful Bill on ZEV adoption, tightening biofuel availability from reduced imports, and proposed EPA rules that could lower RIN generation from fuels produced with imported feedstocks. As a result, tightening LCFS fundamentals and credit balances are expected, driven by reduced clean fuel volumes and a rise in the average carbon intensity of major biofuels such as biomass-based diesel and SAF over the medium to long term. These structural shifts are expected to be bullish for the market in the medium-to-long term.

Implications for Fuel Standards Markets in Neighboring States

With the legislative threat receding in California, market players are also monitoring the contango developing in Oregon’s clean fuels market, where credit prices have recently risen above USD 100 as the state grapples with credit undersupply and looks to draw in fuel from California and Washington. This dynamic could help absorb excess supply from California and soften the impact of the delayed implementation date of the California LCFS rulemaking from 2024.

Next Steps for SB 237

The rest of SB 237 remains largely intact, including a directive for CARB and the California Energy Commission to explore a coordinated regional gasoline specification in partnership with western states. This initiative, aimed at improving supply chain efficiency and reducing production costs, may help stabilize gasoline prices and encourage greater supply. While potentially constructive for gasoline demand, it remains secondary to the clean fuel market focus. SB 237 is scheduled for a hearing on 16 July in the Assembly Committee on Utilities and Energy.

The legislature is on recess from 18 July to 18 August and the session ends 12 September.

title: OPEC+ Accelerates Cut Unwind but Market Remains Tight - Mexico Business News
description:
Since the initial unwind of production cuts in March, the OPEC+ production quota has increased by approximately 1.919MMb/d.
Despite this faster unwinding, oil market indicators continue to suggest the physical market remains tight, implying it should still be able to absorb additional barrels due to seasonally increasing oil demand.
Brent crude oil is forecast to remain stable at $68.0/b through March 2026.
For instance, in April, despite a 138Mb/d quota increase for April, production from these eight countries rose by only 16Mb/d.
Concurrently, analysis of US crude production trends indicates a considerable slowdown in year-on-year growth in recent months.
text:
OPEC+ has continued its accelerated pace of unwinding production cuts, with eight member states agreeing to a production adjustment of 548Mb/d for August. This increase, exceeding market expectations of 411Mb/d, signals the group's response to a "steady global economic outlook and current healthy market fundamentals, as reflected in the low oil inventories," according to UBS.

The decision, reached during a 10-minute meeting on July 5, reflects broad support within the group and reiterates its flexibility, stating that "gradual increases may be paused or reversed subject to evolving market conditions." Since the initial unwind of production cuts in March, the OPEC+ production quota has increased by approximately 1.919MMb/d.

Despite this faster unwinding, oil market indicators continue to suggest the physical market remains tight, implying it should still be able to absorb additional barrels due to seasonally increasing oil demand. However, rising risks, including ongoing trade tensions, suggest the market could appear less tight over the next six to 12 months, posing potential downside risks to prices. Brent crude oil is forecast to remain stable at $68.0/b through March 2026.

According to UBS, most of the announced increases in OPEC+ output may not fully translate into effective supply reaching the market. This is due to several member states still needing to implement compensation cuts for past overproduction and high domestic demand in the Middle East supporting oil consumption for power generation, particularly during hot temperatures. For instance, in April, despite a 138Mb/d quota increase for April, production from these eight countries rose by only 16Mb/d. Similarly, an early April decision to increase the quota by 411Mb/d from May resulted in an effective production increase of just 154Mb/d. OPEC+ crude exports have remained relatively stable versus March.

Concurrently, analysis of US crude production trends indicates a considerable slowdown in year-on-year growth in recent months. Lower oil prices are weighing on drilling activity, suggesting that US crude production might peak this year, particularly if prices experience renewed downward pressure. The report highlights that while the group decided to increase the production quota by 548Mb/d for August (more than anticipated by the market), indicators suggest that the physical crude market remains tight and could absorb additional barrels. Even so, downside risks persist due to trade tensions and slowing oil production growth in the United States. UBS anticipates that most of the announced increases will not be fully reflected in effective supply due to past overproduction from several countries and high domestic demand driven by summer in the Middle East. The Brent price projection remains stable at US$68/b toward the end of the year.

title: Critics rail against federal ​“emergency” forcing coal plants to stay open - Canary Media
description:
State regulators, grid operators, environmentalists, and consumer groups question the logic behind the U.S. Department of Energy’s order forcing the aging J.H.
Campbell coal plant in Michigan and a Pennsylvania coal plant to remain open past their scheduled shutdowns.
(Washington Post) Michigan regulators approve a 55-mile transmission line from the Michigan-Indiana border to a new substation.
(MinnPost) Federal prosecutors seek a 6-year sentence for former ComEd lobbyist Michael McClain, who was convicted with three others of a conspiracy to influence the Illinois state house speaker to assist the utility’s legislation.
(Lincoln Journal-Star) An Ohio county board votes against a proposed 142 MW solar farm, though the Ohio Power Siting Board will make the final regulatory decision.
text:
State regulators, grid operators, environmentalists, and consumer groups question the logic behind the U.S. Department of Energy’s order forcing the aging J.H. Campbell coal plant in Michigan and a Pennsylvania coal plant to remain open past their scheduled shutdowns. (Canary Media)

The Illinois Auditor General reports that Gov. J.B. Pritzker’s administration failed to meet key equity provisions of the state’s law to attain 100% clean energy by 2050. (WAND)

The Indiana Department of Environmental Management announces it will extend the effective time frame for solid and hazardous waste permits, revise air pollution oversight, and make changes to eight other rules because of Gov. Mike Braun’s executive order to find efficiencies in state environmental rules. (Indiana Public Radio)

Ohio regulators back a proposal to charge Amazon, Google, and other tech companies higher rates for high power demand that’s forcing utilities to make costly grid upgrades. (Washington Post)

Michigan regulators approve a 55-mile transmission line from the Michigan-Indiana border to a new substation. (WTVB)

Illinois lawmakers pass a bill to limit carbon capture and sequestration proposals around the Mahomet Aquifer, which supplies water to about 800,000 people and which has been the site of three carbon capture proposals. (Inside Climate News)

Republicans’ federal budget bill could endanger Minnesota’s state law to reach a 100% carbon-free grid by 2040, but utilities say it’s still attainable. (MinnPost)

Federal prosecutors seek a 6-year sentence for former ComEd lobbyist Michael McClain, who was convicted with three others of a conspiracy to influence the Illinois state house speaker to assist the utility’s legislation. (Chicago Tribune)

Kansas regulators approve two 710 MW gas-fired power plants and a 159 MW solar farm for Evergy Inc. despite opposition to the projects. (Lawrence Journal-World)

Panasonic Holdings is reportedly postponing its plan to bring its new, $4 billion Kansas electric vehicle battery plant to full capacity because of sluggish EV sales. (Reuters)

Wisconsin Gov. Tony Evers signs bills to host a nuclear energy summit and direct state regulators to compile a list of pre-certified locations to build reactors at both existing power generation sites and new ones. (Milwaukee Journal Sentinel)

Federal regulators press Holtec International about the need for repairs to steam generator tubes at the 1970s-era Palisades Nuclear Power Plant that was closed three years ago but is set to reopen later this year. (MLive)

Nebraska regulators discuss the possibility of building small modular nuclear reactors in a small city, largely because of its electric transmission infrastructure. (Lincoln Journal-Star)

An Ohio county board votes against a proposed 142 MW solar farm, though the Ohio Power Siting Board will make the final regulatory decision. (Scioto Post)

A report from climate policy think tank Energy Innovation finds Trump’s new budget bill will cost the average Michigan customer $320 annually by 2035 by causing an 8%-15% increase in energy rates from undercutting renewables. (Planet Detroit)

Local and state leaders who represent a Chicago neighborhood push for additional air monitoring and emissions testing at a vegetable oil plant that’s long been the source of complaints from residents. (Block Club Chicago)

text:
Article content

Industry flagship stands alone as the most decorated record-setting business jet of all time, solidifying its position as the leader of the ultra-long-range class

The record-breaking aircraft has set 135 city-pair missions, further highlighting its incredible performance attributes

With more than 200 aircraft in service achieving more than 250,000 flying hours, the proven Global 7500 sets the stage for the company’s Global 8000(2), which is ready to enter into service later this year

Article content

Article content

MONTREAL, July 11, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) — Bombardier today announced that its performance-leading Global 7500 business jet has achieved another record-breaking milestone: 135 speed records(1), the most ever set by a single business aircraft type. Some of the blazing-fast aircraft’s impressive city-pair speed records include key city pairs such as Tokyo to San Francisco, London to Riyadh, Oakland to Tokyo, Hartford to Dubai, Tokyo to Toronto and Montreal to Paris, among many others.

Article content

We apologize, but this video has failed to load.

Try refreshing your browser, or

tap here to see other videos from our team.

Bombardier's Blazing Fast Global 7500 Jet Sets its 135th City-Pair Speed Record, the Most Ever Achieved by a Single Business Aircraft Type Back to video

Article content

Earlier achievements on the Global 7500 include the longest flight ever recorded in business aviation – an 8,225 nautical mile (15,232.7 km) flight from Sydney to Detroit – as well as the industry’s longest range non-stop mission from London City Airport to Los Angeles.

Article content

“This is the ultimate recognition, the most speed records of all time – and it’s precisely what Bombardier’s discerning customers need: a reliable, fast, efficient business tool that gets them to destination quickly and efficiently,” said Jean-Christophe Gallagher, Executive Vice President, Aircraft Sales and Bombardier Defense. “Even more impressive is the fact some of these records have been set with passengers on board in varying conditions and airports. It’s a testament to how well engineered the aircraft is, ensuring customers fully benefit from the aircraft’s outstanding performance attributes for their everyday important missions.”

Article content

Article content

With its incredible performance attributes, the Global 7500 aircraft has achieved an impressive number of speed records since coming to market. Boasting a top speed of Mach 0.925 and a baseline range of 7,700 nautical miles (14,260 km), the Global 7500 sets a new benchmark for performance in the ultra-long-range category. The aircraft’s unique Smooth Flĕx

Wing is like an in-air shock absorber, designed with a sophisticated slats and flap system that generates exceptional lift on takeoff and approach, maximizing aerodynamic efficiency and boosting performance while improving safety and offering the industry’s smoothest ride. It also reduces fuel burn, lowers emissions and produces excellent short-field and high-speed performance – producing the perfect platform for our discerning customers.

Article content

The industry-defining attributes of the Global 7500 aircraft will soon be enhanced with the introduction of the Global 8000 (2) aircraft. Bombardier’s flagship for a new era is anticipated to have an industry-leading range of 8,000 nautical miles (14,816 km) and a top speed of Mach 0.94, making it the ultimate all-in-one business aircraft. It will also have a low cabin altitude of less than 2,900 feet when flying at 41,000 ft.

title: Congress, state lawmakers move to juice aviation biofuel production
description:
Lawmakers in Iowa, Wisconsin, Michigan and New York have introduced bills enacting tax credits for sustainable aviation fuel.
While the credit’s lifetime was extended, others say the environment for sustainable aviation fuel isn't as favorable as it was just a few years ago.
Corn ethanol, a common ingredient in automotive fuel, can be used to make sustainable aviation fuel.
It’s now the equivalent to what other biofuel producers qualify for, giving sustainable aviation fuel production less of a competitive advantage.
But Greenough cautioned that sentiment around sustainable aviation fuel still isn’t as rosy as it used to be.
text:
Congress’ passage of President Donald Trump’s spending and tax cuts bill this month could help grow the market for sustainable aviation fuel, a nascent industry that could be a boon for corn-producing states as airline operators are betting on it to decarbonize the sector.

The Republican budget reconciliation law that Trump signed July 4 pared back some of the credits for sustainable energy in the law that congressional Democrats passed and President Joe Biden signed in 2022 — the Inflation Reduction Act.

But the recent law extended one energy tax credit for producing clean fuels, such as sustainable aviation fuel, an alternative to the typical jet fuel planes use. The credit initially went through 2027, but the GOP law extends it through 2029.

Advocates for sustainable aviation fuel had been pushing Congress to extend the tax credit to support production as states across the U.S. have passed or proposed their own tax credits to grow the sector and lure production within their borders. Lawmakers in Iowa, Wisconsin, Michigan and New York have introduced bills enacting tax credits for sustainable aviation fuel.

For airlines, increasing availability of the fuel is essential for the sector to meet its net-zero goal for 2050, with the International Air Transport Association estimating the cleaner fuel could get the industry 65% of the way toward its target.

“We’re not yet at commercial-scale production and you need that longer lead time for these types of projects so I think the extension is really key,” said Chris Bliley, senior vice president of regulatory affairs at Growth Energy, a biofuel industry group.

While the credit’s lifetime was extended, others say the environment for sustainable aviation fuel isn't as favorable as it was just a few years ago. The new budget reconciliation law also included provisions to lower the credit amount for sustainable aviation fuel specifically and clawed back unobligated grant funding to support the sector.

The amount of sustainable aviation fuel that producers make today is far from how much the airline industry needs to be able to use the alternative fuel regularly. U.S. production capacity over the last couple of years, however, has grown, jumping from less than 5,000 barrels per day at the start of 2024 to more than 30,000 by February of this year, according to a May report from the U.S. Energy Information Administration.

Badger State bill

Wisconsin state Rep. David Steffen, a Republican who sponsored a bill to incentivize sustainable aviation fuel, said he learned about a sustainable aviation fuel production company based in Madison called Virent Inc., now a subsidiary of Marathon Petroleum Corp. Virent’s fuel helped power the first domestic flight powered by 100% sustainable aviation fuel in one of its engines.

“I was intrigued that we had this company in our state and I want them and other companies of similar interest to find Wisconsin as their new home,” Steffen said. “It’s a great opportunity for not only the environmental benefits that come with it but for our farmers, dairies and timber producers to access a brand-new market for their product.”

Steffen’s bill also requires that to receive the tax credit, source materials for the fuel must be domestically sourced.

Wisconsin’s legislative session doesn’t end until next March and Steffen said he’s “very comfortable in saying (the bill) will have a clear path to the finish line.” Should it pass in its current state, the tax credit would go into effect in 2028.

Other states

Iowa, Illinois, Minnesota, Nebraska and Washington state all already have enacted laws to provide tax credits for sustainable aviation fuel.

Lawmakers in New York and Michigan have also proposed legislation to create their own tax credits. The New York bill barely moved in the most recent session, while legislation in Michigan has made it out of one committee and been referred to a second.

New York state Sen. Rachel May, a Democrat, plans to re-introduce the legislation next year. She said she wants to amend her bill to offer a larger tax credit for companies making sustainable aviation fuel specifically by mimicking photosynthesis so it doesn’t incentivize diverting feedstock like corn from being used for food, she said.

Her concern is moving the agriculture industry “away from both food production and maybe what might be the best uses of the land,” she added.

Corn ethanol, a common ingredient in automotive fuel, can be used to make sustainable aviation fuel.

Federal extension

While the extension of the federal clean fuels tax credit could be beneficial to the sustainable aviation fuel industry, the new law also lowers the amount of the tax credit for the fuel. It’s now the equivalent to what other biofuel producers qualify for, giving sustainable aviation fuel production less of a competitive advantage.

One version of the budget reconciliation bill also called for extending the tax credit by four years instead of two, but that got scaled back in the version of the bill ultimately signed into law.

The new law also took away any funding not yet obligated as part of a grant program for sustainable aviation fuel and makes fuels derived from feedstocks that come from outside the U.S., Canada or Mexico ineligible for the tax credit.

Despite any limitations, some analysts expect the law will still boost sustainable aviation fuel.

“The Trump administration has yet to outline its approach to SAF, but we expect the fuel to benefit from the administration’s focus on supporting biofuel-producing states,” analysts for Capstone DC, a firm that advises business clients on policy issues, said in a note in late June.

But changes to the federal tax credit could also make states more interested in adopting their own credit to support sustainable aviation fuel, Capstone added.

‘Not nearly as strong’

Tariffs, meanwhile, could also make U.S. feedstocks for producing the fuel more competitive, Paul Greenough, a vice president on Capstone’s energy team.

But Greenough cautioned that sentiment around sustainable aviation fuel still isn’t as rosy as it used to be.

“Momentum still exists for SAF but it’s not nearly as strong as it was under the Biden administration,” he said.

Some climate groups have also expressed concern over changing the clean fuels tax credit at the federal level. The Clean Air Task Force, ahead of the bill becoming law, said extending the credit will largely service other fuels that aren’t sustainable aviation fuel, which will in turn be costlier for the government.

title: 10th Global Infrastructure Initiative Summit - World Energy
description:
Sept. 9-11, 2025 – Beverly Hills, CA McKinsey’s 10th Global Infrastructure Initiative Summit will bring together the world’s leaders in infrastructure and capital projects at a pivotal moment for the sector.
World Energy CEO, Gene Gebolys, will take part in the Picking up the Pace on the Global Energy Transition panel.
Gene and his fellow panelist will discuss how global infrastructure and energy leaders are uniting in their commitment to sustainability, but rapidly achieving net-zero remains a daunting task.

text:
Sept. 9-11, 2025 – Beverly Hills, CA

McKinsey’s 10th Global Infrastructure Initiative Summit will bring together the world’s leaders in infrastructure and capital projects at a pivotal moment for the sector.

World Energy CEO, Gene Gebolys, will take part in the Picking up the Pace on the Global Energy Transition panel. Gene and his fellow panelist will discuss how global infrastructure and energy leaders are uniting in their commitment to sustainability, but rapidly achieving net-zero remains a daunting task. The discussion will explore what critical steps and considerations are essential for substantially accelerating the energy transition, and how stakeholders can work together to plan, finance, and execute green projects more swiftly.

title: Navigating OBBBA: phaseouts, prohibited foreign entity rules, and other new rules
description:
The prohibited foreign entity rules Like all prior iterations of the legislation, the OBBBA as enacted includes a thicket of new and complex prohibited foreign entity (“PFE”) rules that will, at minimum, impose significant compliance burdens on taxpayers.
The PFE rules fall into three categories: Entity-level rules that disallow several clean energy tax credits if the taxpayer is a PFE — either a specified foreign entity (“SFE”) or a foreign influenced entity (“FIE”).
Under the entity-level rules, taxpayers will need to determine whether they themselves are SFEs or FIEs.
What does compliance with the entity-level SFE rules look like going forward?
The final bill does not apply foreign entity rules or make any other changes to the section 45V credit.
text:
This post builds on the briefs we published on June 20 (the House draft) and June 30 (the Senate draft) and describes the energy credit provisions as enacted in the final version of the recently-enacted reconciliation bill (“OBBBA”). We have also published updated slides, including additional examples, which demonstrate the complexity of the new prohibited foreign entity rules, which many taxpayers seeking credits will need to understand and comply with going forward. We will continue to update this post and slides based on continued analysis and implementing guidance.

Last week, both houses of Congress approved a final version of the budget reconciliation bill, and President Trump signed the bill into law. Like earlier versions of this legislation, the law terminates many clean energy incentives almost immediately, including those for clean vehicles and home energy efficiency. It phases out the major investment tax credit (ITC) and production tax credit (PTC) for wind and solar energy within a short timeframe but continues those credits for other technologies, including energy storage, geothermal, hydropower, and nuclear. The law also includes complex and onerous new “prohibited foreign entity” rules that apply to the ITC and PTC, to the credit for clean energy-related manufacturing, and to a lesser degree to other clean energy tax credits. While drastically reducing tax incentives for clean energy, the final bill includes new tax cuts for oil, natural gas, and coal and leaves in place the many existing tax benefits enjoyed by fossil fuel industries.

Below is an analysis of what is in the final bill and what compliance looks like going forward, including:

Phaseouts and terminations

“Beginning of construction”

Prohibited foreign entity rules:

Entity-level rules

Specified foreign entities

Foreign-influenced entities

Payments

Material assistance

Other changes to clean energy credits

1. Phaseouts and Terminations

The final bill leaves in place the direct pay and transferability mechanisms, as well as the prevailing wage and apprenticeship (PWA) rules and other credit bonuses.

2. "Beginning of construction"

What does it mean to begin construction on a project?

For generation and hydrogen credits, under OBBBA, taxpayers will need to determine whether they can begin construction on projects in time. In general, solar and wind projects must commence by July 4, 2026, to claim the section 45Y or 48E credits. A solar or wind project commencing construction after that date must be placed in service by December 31, 2027, in order to be eligible for generation tax credits under sections 45Y or 48E. Other generation technologies and energy storage must commence before the end of 2033 to obtain the full value of the section 45Y or 48E credits, or by 2035 for partial value. (The legislation clarifies that energy storage at a wind or solar facility is eligible for the ITC for that longer period.) Hydrogen facilities must begin construction before the end of 2027 to claim the section 45V credit.

The new law does not change the definition of “beginning of construction.” The meaning of the term has been well understood in the context of energy tax credits for many years based on consistent IRS guidance dating back to 2013. The IRS has provided guidance providing two common pathways for taxpayers to demonstrate that they have begun construction: if they start physical work of a significant nature (the “physical work test”) or if they pay or incur at least 5% of the total project cost. Under both the physical work test and the 5% safe harbor, taxpayers must maintain continuous progress toward project completion (the “continuity requirement”). Whether taxpayers meet this requirement is based on the applicable facts and circumstances, but they are deemed to satisfy the continuity requirement if they place the project in service within four years of commencement.

These rules and safe harbors are set forth in Notice 2013-29 (describing the safe harbor tests and continuity rule as they apply generally to the PTC/ITC under 45/48) and Notice 2018-59 (providing more clarity and detail about how these rules apply specifically to ITC projects). Similar rules have been applied to sections 45Q, 48E, 45Y, 30C, 45V, 179D, and 48D.

Congress has modified the eligibility deadlines for energy tax credits several times based on beginning of construction dates without changing these IRS rules — including in OBBBA. In fact, OBBBA includes a provision seemingly intended to codify the IRS’s longstanding beginning of construction rules, which references Notice 2013-29 and Notice 2018-59. Confusingly, however, the provision only explicitly applies to a new paragraph of the tax code (section 7701(a)(51)) that includes definitions of “prohibited foreign entities” — definitions that do not contain the phrase “beginning of construction.” Our reading of the final text is that “beginning of construction” is presumed to be consistently used throughout the bill. The statutory reference to Notice 2013-29 affirms that the consistent body of past IRS guidance should apply.

How does the recent executive order (EO) impact beginning of construction?

Notwithstanding our reading of the text and the statutory structure, taxpayers should be aware that the White House issued an EO on July 7 directing Treasury to issue guidance to ensure the beginning of construction rules are not circumvented, stating the following:

Within 45 days following enactment of the One Big Beautiful Bill Act, the Secretary of the Treasury shall take all action as the Secretary of the Treasury deems necessary and appropriate to strictly enforce the termination of the clean electricity production and investment tax credits under sections 45Y and 48E of the Internal Revenue Code for wind and solar facilities. This includes issuing new and revised guidance as the Secretary of the Treasury deems appropriate and consistent with applicable law to ensure that policies concerning the “beginning of construction” are not circumvented, including by preventing the artificial acceleration or manipulation of eligibility and by restricting the use of broad safe harbors unless a substantial portion of a subject facility has been built.

This executive order is not law, and the scope of the Treasury and IRS guidance called for by the executive order (and when it will become effective) is unclear. However, consistent with the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and typical practice of the IRS, any new subregulatory guidance would presumably be prospective and subject to abuse of discretion review under the APA.

Taxpayers will need to work closely with their advisors to plan and understand the activities that will satisfy the beginning of construction rules and take into account any new guidance issued under the executive order.

3. The prohibited foreign entity rules

Like all prior iterations of the legislation, the OBBBA as enacted includes a thicket of new and complex prohibited foreign entity (“PFE”) rules that will, at minimum, impose significant compliance burdens on taxpayers. It is unclear why OBBBA applies these rules solely to a subset of energy credits and not the countless other subsidies that exist in the tax code — including tax benefits for fossil fuel energy sources and the many new tax breaks created by OBBBA.

In any event, the PFE rules are now law, and taxpayers must understand them in order to comply with the law if they are seeking tax credits. This section explains the three new sets of PFE rules and identifies key steps and key ambiguities.

The PFE rules fall into three categories:

Entity-level rules that disallow several clean energy tax credits if the taxpayer is a PFE — either a specified foreign entity (“SFE”) or a foreign influenced entity (“FIE”).

Payments rules under which taxpayers can lose eligibility for the 45Y, 48E, or 45X tax credits (or even have to repay 48E credits claimed up to a decade prior) if they make payments that are deemed to confer “effective control” to an SFE.

Material assistance rules that require taxpayers to determine if the manufactured products comprising their facilities (for 45Y and 48E) or inputs into the components they produce (for 45X) derive excessively from PFEs.

The following table outlines the key phase-in dates for the new PFE restrictions (bracketed dates shown for calendar year taxpayers):

OBBBA does not apply foreign entity rules to certain other energy credits, including the PTC and ITC for projects placed in service before 2025 (sections 45 and 48), the continuing ITC for geothermal heat pumps (also section 48), the section 45V clean hydrogen production credit, and the many clean energy credits that the law terminates within a year. It does, however, prohibit transfers of credits to SFEs under section 6418.

a. Entity-level rules

The new law establishes two categories of PFEs: (1) SFEs and (2) FIEs. Generally speaking, the law makes both types of entities ineligible for tax credits under sections 45Y, 48E, 45X, 45Q, 45U, and 45Z, with some differences in rules for different credits.

Under the entity-level rules, taxpayers will need to determine whether they themselves are SFEs or FIEs. As described in more detail in the following sections, the payments and material assistance rules also reference the definitions of SFE and FIE, which means that taxpayers will also need to determine whether certain counterparties or suppliers are SFEs or FIEs.

What are the SFE rules?

The 45Y, 48E, 45X, 45Q, 45U, and 45Z credits are disallowed for SFEs beginning in the first taxable year after the date of enactment. For calendar year taxpayers, this will generally mean calendar year 2026.

An entity is deemed an SFE, if on the last day of the taxable year, it is either (a) included on various lists under national security laws, including organizations that are designated as threats to national security by a variety of federal agencies, Chinese battery companies, and companies listed as part of the Uyghur Forced Labor Prevention Act, or (b) a “foreign controlled entity.”

A foreign controlled entity includes

a government of a “covered nation” (North Korea, Iran, Russia, & China),

a citizen or national of a covered nation (excluding U.S. citizens and lawful permanent residents),

an entity or qualified business unit incorporated or organized under laws of a covered nation or an entity having its principal place of business in a covered nation, or

any entity “controlled” by such entities.

“Control” means an entity owning greater than 50% vote or value, greater than 50% profit or capital interests, or greater than 50% of the beneficial ownership. Only section 318(a)(2) (upward attribution) applies in determining indirect ownership. In simple terms, this means that the ownership analysis is limited to testing entities/individuals that sit above the U.S. taxpayer in the chain of ownership, including partners and shareholders. We have included specific examples demonstrating how this ownership analysis works in our updated slides, which we encourage readers to review.

Importantly, US taxpayers do not need to examine/test the familial relationships (e.g., spouses, children, parents, siblings) of their owners/shareholders or whether related subsidiaries (i.e. those owned by a common parent) are foreign controlled entities. This expansive type of attribution testing, at least for purposes of testing for SFEs, was included in earlier versions of the bill but not included in the final legislation, meaning taxpayers only need to test the entities/shareholders sitting above them in the chain of ownership.

What does compliance with the entity-level SFE rules look like going forward?

U.S. taxpayers will generally know whether they are classified as a threat to national security or one of the entities included on the various lists referenced above. SFE testing for most taxpayers will therefore mainly consist of looking up the chain of ownership to determine whether any governments of covered nations, citizens of covered nations, or entities organized in covered nations own the taxpayer directly, or indirectly through another entity.

Determining whether a foreign controlled entity directly owns more than 50% of the taxpayer is relatively straightforward – the taxpayer considers its immediate shareholders, partners, or beneficial owners. Determining whether a foreign controlled entity indirectly owns more than 50% is more complicated, but it may still be manageable.

Critical to this analysis is when and how a taxpayer must attribute ownership proportionately to an entity several legs up the chain. For stock owned by an entity other than a corporation or trust (like a partnership) to a foreign controlled entity, taxpayers must attribute ownership proportionally up the chain regardless of the percentage of stock owned (under section 318(a)(2)(A)). So, if a Chinese entity owns 49% of US Partnership, which owns 25% of US Corp, the Chinese entity is treated as proportionally owning 12.25% of US Corp (49% x 25%).

If, however, stock owned by a corporation is being attributed to a foreign controlled entity, the stock is only attributed proportionally if the foreign controlled entity owns 50% (by value) or more of the stock of the corporation sitting immediately below it (under section 318(a)(2)(C)). So, if a Chinese entity owns 49% of US Corp 1, who owns 25% of US Corp 2, the Chinese entity is treated as proportionally owning 0% of US Corp 2. Ownership percentages are not multiplied up the chain, because the Chinese entity doesn’t own a sufficient amount of stock in US Corp 1 to be treated under section 318(a)(2)(C) as proportionally owning the stock that US Corp 1 owns.

The proportional ownership rules are slightly less clear if the ownership interest is something other than stock, since section 318 only covers stock ownership. OBBBA says that “similar” rules should apply when attributing non-stock interests for purposes of PFE testing, and we include examples in our linked slide deck showing how attribution presumably works in such cases.

Finally, even if a taxpayer is not excluded as an SFE by virtue of 50%+ Chinese (or Russian, Iranian, or North Korean) ownership (as in the examples above), other rules, discussed below, may exclude taxpayers that have less than 50% Chinese ownership thresholds.

What are the FIE rules?

The FIE rules apply to taxpayers seeking credits under sections 45Y, 48E, 45X, 45Q, 45U, and 45Z, except for the effective control payment test within the FIE rules (described below), which only applies to 45Y, 48E, and 45X. The FIE rules apply to 45Y, 48E, 45X, and 45Q in the taxable year after enactment and apply to 45Z and 45U in taxable years beginning after 2 years after the date of enactment.

Credits are disallowed if the taxpayer is an FIE, and like prior iterations of the OBBB, the FIE definitions layer onto the SFE definitions. An entity is an FIE if, on the last day of the tax year

an SFE has the direct authority to appoint a covered officer;,

a single SFE owns at least 25% of the entity,

one or more SFEs own at least 40% of the entity, or

at least 15% of the entity’s debt has been issued, in the aggregate, to one or more SFEs.

For the 45Y, 48E, and 45Z credits only, an entity is also deemed an FIE if it makes a payment to an SFE that is deemed to confer effective control. Since the payments rule is different in nature than the other FIE tests and very complex, we discuss it in the next section.

What is the publicly traded entity exception for the PFE rules?

The final version of the OBBBA provides modified SFE and FIE rules for publicly traded entities whose securities are regularly traded on a national securities exchange registered with the SEC (as well as several other types of markets and exchanges, but not a covered nation’s exchange).

First, for such publicly traded entities, the bill turns off the regular foreign controlled entity rule in section 7701(a)(51)(C)(v) that treats entities as SFEs if they are controlled by a government, citizen, or entity organized in a covered nation. It replaces this rule with a new (but similar) rule, which is that a publicly traded entity will be treated as a foreign controlled entity (and therefore an SFE) if the entity is controlled (i.e. >50% owned applying 318(a)(2)) by either

one or more SFEs listed on various national security lists, or

one or more governments of, citizens/nationals of, or entities organized in a covered nation,

who are required to report their beneficial ownership of the entity under SEC Rule 13d-3.

This rule provides some relief from the SFE rules for these companies, because shareholders only report as beneficial owners under 13d-3 if they own more than 5% of equity securities. Public companies therefore only need to track foreign connections of individual shareholders with large (>5%) ownership interests.

Second, for such publicly traded entities and their 80% owned subsidiaries, the final bill turns off the regular FIE triggers and replaces them with new (but again, very similar) FIE triggers. A publicly traded entity (and 80% subsidiaries) will be treated as an FIE if

an SFE has the authority (presumably including direct and indirect authority) to appoint a covered officer.

a single SFE who reports its beneficial ownership of the entity under 13d-3 owns at least 25%.

one or more SFEs who report beneficial ownership of the entity under 13d-3 own, in the aggregate, at least 40%, or

the publicly traded entity or its 80% sub has issued debt in excess of 15% of its publicly traded debt to one or more SFEs.

Importantly, publicly traded entities are, however, still subject to the full suite of effective control payment and material assistance rules, meaning these modified rules provide only limited relief.

What does FIE compliance look like going forward?

FIE compliance is going to require three key things.

Ownership: First, taxpayers need to look at their direct owners (i.e. immediate owners) and indirect owners (i.e. entities further up the ownership chain) to determine whether any of those entities are SFEs. The same attribution and proportional ownership rules of section 318(a)(2) that we described above apply. This task may seem daunting, because taxpayers will first need to perform SFE testing on their owners. In many (perhaps most) cases, however, the ownership analysis for SFE and FIE testing will merge, assuming taxpayers aren’t indirectly owned by entities included on various national security lists. Like the SFE test, the key FIE analysis for many taxpayers will also consist of looking up the chain of ownership to determine whether any governments of covered nations, citizens of covered nations, or entities organized in covered nations own the taxpayer directly, or indirectly through another entity. Based on this information, taxpayers will determine which owners are SFEs and then whether any single SFE owns 25% of the taxpayer or whether one or more SFEs own at least 40% in the aggregate. Part of this analysis will inherently involve understanding whether an SFE has direct authority to appoint a covered officer, which in many cases would only occur where the SFE is an immediate owner, not one that sits several entities up the chain.

Debt: Second, taxpayers need to look at whom their debt was “issued” to. The final OBBBA text moved away from requiring taxpayers to determine the percentage of debt “held by” SFEs to now require taxpayers to determine the percentage “issued to” SFEs. Though it is unknown how Treasury/IRS guidance would interpret this language, until guidance is released, our reading of the statute and the drafting history suggests that the analysis requires looking at the first issuance. For example, in the case of municipal bonds, a more than reasonable interpretation of the statute would suggest that a bond issuer seeking a tax credit would only test whether the underwriter is an SFE, not every investor who eventually holds the debt.

Payments: Third, taxpayers claiming 45Y, 48E, and 45X need to test contracts related to their qualified facilities and the production of eligible components to determine whether a payment was made to an SFE under a contract conferring “effective control.” This requirement applies for 10 years for credits claimed under section 48E (subject to recapture) and each year a credit is claimed under 45Y or 45X. Step 1 requires analyzing (a) whether the terms of contracts related to the taxpayer’s qualified facility, energy storage technology (EST), or production of eligible components confer effective control to a counterparty and (b) whether agreements with respect to such facilities and production confer effective control. Step 2 is to find out whether the payment recipient/counterparty to the agreement is an SFE. We discuss these steps in more detail below.

FIE compliance is onerous and complex. But it is not impossible. Taxpayers are likely to be able to satisfy these rules as long as they understand them and carefully apply each step of the analysis. Buckle up and keep reading.

b. Payments rules

The payments rules apply to the 45Y, 48E, and 45X credits. Under the payments rules, a single “bad” payment can have major repercussions, so taxpayers will need to understand the rules and monitor their contracts closely.

The payments rules are triggered if, during the prior taxable year, the entity makes a payment to an SFE under an agreement that gives the SFE “effective control” over either (1) a qualified facility or EST of the taxpayer or any person related to the taxpayer, or (2) critical mineral/eligible component production by the taxpayer or a person related to the taxpayer.

If a taxpayer has made any such payment in a prior year, it is deemed to be an FIE for the current year. The taxpayer will lose any credits for the facility (45Y/48E) or the production (45X) for the current year — and potentially credits from prior years, as discussed below.

The legislation is unclear whether a payment that is deemed to confer “effective control” over one facility renders the taxpayer an FIE for all purposes, which would mean that it loses credits for any other facility it has.

The general rule is that payments conferring effective control are those made pursuant to contracts that give one or more counterparties “specific authority over key aspects of the production of eligible components, energy generation in a qualified facility, or energy storage.”

Taxpayers claiming tax credits under sections 45Y or 45X must monitor effective control payments in each year prior to the year they claim a tax credit or risk losing their credit for the subsequent year. Starting in 2028, taxpayers claiming tax credits under section 48E must monitor effective control payments (including potentially those for other facilities owned by the taxpayer) for a 10-year period beginning in the year prior to claiming the credit or risk having the credit recaptured. It is unclear whether a payment with respect to one facility can trigger recapture of prior section 48E tax credits for other facilities.

How can taxpayers comply with the payments rules to avoid triggering them?

Below, we describe the two main steps to compliance.

Step 1: Identify contracts/agreements related to qualified facilities, EST, or the production of eligible components that potentially confer effective control

Step 1 is for taxpayers to analyze all contracts related to their qualified facilities, EST, and production of eligible components to determine if such contracts fall into either of two categories of contracts conferring effective control.

Category I includes any contracts including triggering terms conferring “effective control.” Prior to the issuance of guidance (and likely after the issuance of guidance as well), that means contracts that provide counterparties any one of six specific contractual rights, including rights to

determine the quantity or timing of production of an eligible component produced by the taxpayer;

determine the amount or timing of activities related to the production of electricity at a qualified facility or the storage of energy in EST of the taxpayer;

determine which entity may purchase or use the output of a production unit that produces eligible components;

determine which entity may purchase or use the output of a qualified facility of the taxpayer;

restrict access to data critical to production or storage of energy at a qualified facility, or to the site of production or any part of a qualified facility or EST of the taxpayer, to personnel or agents of the counterparty; or

exclusively maintain, repair, or operate any plant or equipment which is necessary to the production by the taxpayer of eligible components or electricity.

Category II includes licensing agreements for the provision of intellectual property (IP) (and contracts related to such agreements) “with respect” to a qualified facility, EST, or the production of an eligible component that contain any one of six contractual rights/terms, including terms or rights that

specify or otherwise direct one or more sources of components, subcomponents, or applicable critical minerals;

direct the operation of any qualified facility, any EST, or any production unit that produces an eligible component;

limit the taxpayer’s utilization of IP related to the operation of the qualified facility, EST, or production of an eligible component;

receive royalties under the licensing agreement or similar agreement beyond the 10th year of the agreement;

direct or require the taxpayer to enter into an agreement for the provision of services for a duration longer than two years; or

do not provide the licensee (the taxpayer) with all the technical data, info, and know-how necessary to produce the eligible component(s) subject to the agreement without further involvement from the counterparty/SFE.

In addition, category II also includes any licensing agreement for the provision of IP with respect to a qualified facility, EST, or production of eligible components that is entered into or modified after enactment (July 4, 2025), regardless of whether the contract contains one of the six contractual IP rights/terms above. Given the breadth of the payment rules related to licensing, a best practice for taxpayers is to assume that all licensing agreements warrant further analysis described in step 2.

Step 2: Determine whether counterparties/payment recipients of contracts conferring effective control are SFEs

After determining whether any contracts fall into categories I or II, step 2 is to find out whether the counterparties to such contracts are SFEs. In order to run afoul of the payment rules, the contract must (1) result in payment to an SFE, and (2) confer effective control to an SFE or person “related” to an SFE under sections 267(b) or 707(b). Importantly, a plain reading of the text indicates that the entity must make a payment to an SFE, not just a person related to an SFE, to violate the rule. Once a taxpayer determines that a payment has been/will be made to an SFE under the contract, then the taxpayer must determine whether the contract gives effective control over the facility or production (including the facility or production of a related person) to an SFE or a person related to an SFE (under the principles of 267(b) and 707(b), which are extremely broad).

The upshot of this reading is that taxpayers would not need to perform the related person portion of this analysis unless the payment recipient and counterparty receiving effective control are different persons/entities under the contract. Taxpayers should monitor future guidance on this closely, however. Additionally, any single payment, no matter how small, can trigger these rules. Contracts falling into the contract categories described above must therefore be reviewed closely for compliance.

It is also worth noting that determining the SFE status of a counterparty could be difficult; the counterparty may not know whether it is an SFE or want to share its ownership structure with the taxpayer. And, the statute does not provide any specific path to obtaining certification from counterparties nor does it provide a “knowingly” standard, meaning taxpayers can violate the rule regardless of knowledge or reasonable efforts. That said, taxpayers will need to devise measures to get comfortable with compliance, which could still potentially involve the use of certifying statements from counterparties or similar.

Are existing contracts safe from the FIE effective control payment test?

In short, no. Taxpayers claiming credits under sections 45Y, 48E, and 45X will be subject to the FIE rules beginning in taxable years 2026 regardless of when they commenced construction and regardless of whether they are in the middle of their 45Y or 45X credit period. Those taxpayers are party to existing contracts, and payments made in the prior year pursuant to those contracts are subject to these effective control payment rules.

c. Material assistance rules

What are the final material assistance rules?

OBBBA denies 45Y and 48E credits if the construction of a facility or EST includes “material assistance” from a prohibited foreign entity. Material assistance essentially means that too much of the facility or EST was produced by PFEs, as determined by a set of highly complex rules that apply to facilities and EST beginning construction after 2025. Similarly, OBBBA denies 45X credits if eligible components are made with too many inputs from PFEs. The 45X material assistance rules apply to components sold in taxable years beginning after the date of enactment.

Whether a facility, EST, or eligible component satisfies the material assistance rules is determined by a “material assistance cost ratio.” That ratio must meet certain threshold percentages, which escalate year-by-year. In simple terms, the cost ratio is the total cost of non-PFE parts divided by the total cost of all parts incorporated into the facility or eligible component. Below, we describe in more detail how the ratios are calculated for qualified facilities, EST, and eligible components, and which “parts” appear to be subject to the analysis.

For qualified facilities and EST, the cost ratio equals

For 45X eligible components, the cost ratio equals

In order to determine these ratios, taxpayers will need to understand what constitutes “manufactured products” for qualified facilities/EST and what constitutes “direct material costs” for 45X eligible components and critical minerals, which we discuss below. Taxpayers must ensure that the ratios for each qualified facility or eligible component meet the required statutory thresholds. For qualified facilities and EST, those thresholds are based on when the facility begins construction; for eligible components it is based on when the component is sold.

Here are the statutory thresholds for qualified facilities and EST:

And here are the thresholds for 45X eligible components, which differ depending on the type of eligible component sold:

Notably, Treasury is directed to adjust the applicable critical minerals percentages upward based on domestic geographic availability, supply chain constraints, domestic processing capacity needs, and national security concerns.

What is included in “manufactured product” for 45Y/48E and “direct material cost” for 45X?

For 45Y/48E, the final bill defines “manufactured product” as “a component of a qualified facility, as described in section 45Y(g)(11)(B) and any guidance issued thereunder” or any product identified by Treasury in subsequent guidance. Section 45Y(g)(11)(B) contains the requirements for the domestic content bonus. It defines manufactured product by reference to the Buy America regulations under section 661 of title 49, which distinguishes between manufactured product and steel and iron that is not incorporated into components, like structural steel and iron. Given this reference, it appears that the material assistance rules only require taxpayers to determine the sourcing of manufactured products, including components, not structural steel or iron, which presumably is excluded from the cost ratio calculation. In the language of the domestic content regime established in Notice 2023-38, this would mean taxpayers need to evaluate applicable project components (“APCs”) that are manufactured products; it is ambiguous whether taxpayers would also need to evaluate manufactured product components (“MPCs”) - i.e. whether the parenthetical “(including components)” in the cost ratio formula is meant to refer to MPCs.

In this respect, like prior iterations of the bill, the final OBBBA text remains ambiguous regarding how far up the supply chain taxpayers must look when calculating the cost ratio. However, in the final text, the cost ratio is calculated based upon “direct costs” (48E/45Y) and “direct material costs” (45X) in accordance with the meaning under section 461 and any regulations issued under 263A. In particular, during Senate floor consideration of OBBBA, “costs” for 48E/45Y were clarified to be “direct costs.” The term direct costs is an indication that the law only requires the taxpayer to analyze purchases that it makes without looking through to embedded components - but it remains unclear.

The text directs Treasury to issue safe harbor cost tables and other guidance by December 31, 2026, to identify “direct costs” of any manufactured products attributable to a PFE and the “direct material costs” of any eligible components attributable to a PFE, presumably by facility/component type. In the interim, taxpayers have the option of using the safe harbor tables included in Notice 2025-08, both for purposes of 45Y/48E and 45X, and to rely on certifications from suppliers stating that a product was not produced by a PFE (i.e. a production certification). In the interim they also have the option to obtain and rely on certifications from suppliers stating the “total direct costs or the total direct material costs, as applicable, of such product or component that was not produced or manufactured by a prohibited foreign entity” (i.e. a cost certification). Taxpayers cannot rely on product and cost certifications that they know or have reason to know are inaccurate and are subject to penalties if they violate this rule. Suppliers are also subject to penalties for false statements made in certifications.

What must be included in the optional supplier certification?

The supplier certification must include the supplier’s employer ID number or similar number issued by a foreign government, be signed under penalty of perjury, and be retained by the supplier and taxpayer for at least 6 years. The certification must state that the supplier does not know or have reason to know that (1) the property the taxpayer purchased was produced or manufactured by a PFE and (2) “that any prior supplier in the chain of production of that property is a prohibited foreign entity.” In addition, for 45X, the certification must specify the total direct material costs for the components and subcomponents that were not produced by a PFE, and for 45Y/48E, the total direct cost attributed to manufactured products that were not produced by a PFE.

This certification requirement appears to be mismatched with the substantive cost ratio requirements, which do not appear to require tracing fully up the chain, and with the provisions allowing taxpayers to use the safe harbor cost tables provided in Notice 2025-08.

How do taxpayers use the safe harbor tables provided in Notice 2025-08 leading up to new guidance? What’s the path forward for technologies without tables?

Notice 2025-08 helps taxpayers claim the domestic content bonus. It provides default cost percentages for APCs and MPCs. Under Notice 2023-38 (domestic content guidance), APCs are items that are directly incorporated into a project (i.e. directly incorporated into a qualified facility or into energy storage technology). MPCs are items that are directly incorporated into a manufactured product. Under the domestic content rules, the origin of subcomponents is not considered, so taxpayers do not need to analyze further upstream than the MPC level. The tables in Notice 2025-08 are meant to be used as exclusive lists of components.

How taxpayers should use the tables in Notice 2025-08 for the material assistance cost ratio is not entirely clear. The tables list manufactured products (referred to in the tables as APCs) for solar, land-based wind, and battery storage projects. The tables break each manufactured product into components (referred to in the tables as MPCs), and ascribe default cost percentages to each component and to production of the manufactured product.

It seems evident that since OBBBA gives taxpayers the option of relying on the domestic content tables, they only need to determine – at most – whether the APCs and MPCs in their projects were produced by prohibited foreign entities without looking further upstream. If subcomponents were part of the analysis, the tables would provide little or no help. But given that the material assistance cost ratio is based on “direct costs,” it is not clear whether taxpayers determine their cost ratio at the APC level or the MPC level.

So, what would that look like? As an example, if the analysis were applied at an MPC level, assume a taxpayer seeks to develop and place in service a qualified facility that is a land-based wind facility. Notice 2025-08 specifically provides a cost percentage table for the APC and MPCs incorporated into such a facility:

The table indicates that the nacelle (an MPC) makes up 47.5% of the cost of all MPCs in a land-based wind facility, and the rest of the MPCs make up the other roughly 52.5%. Assuming the taxpayer purchases nacelles from a non-PFE and all other MPCs from PFEs, the cost ratio for this facility would presumably be 47.5% (the non-PFE total direct manufactured product cost/total direct manufactured product cost), which would meet the cost ratio threshold for facilities beginning construction in 2026. This assumes that the “direct cost” referred to in the statute refers to the purchase cost of MPCs, meaning purchasing the MPC from a non-PFE is sufficient.

This approach, however, carries risk given the references to supply chain tracing in the supplier certification rules.

If the analysis is performed at a APC and MPC level, for facility types that are not included in Notice 2025-28, including nuclear, hydropower, geothermal, and fuel cells, taxpayers will need to make their own determination about which components are considered APCs and MPCs and perform their own cost analysis based on the best reading of the statute. This will be a difficult task, and many taxpayers will likely need to wait for the IRS to issue safe harbor tables.

In applying the material assistance rules, do taxpayers need to determine whether their suppliers have made any payments to SFEs that trigger the effective control rules, rendering the supplier a “foreign-influenced entity”?

The effective control payment rule appears to apply only to the taxpayer and the contracts they enter into with respect to their qualified facilities or their production of eligible components. That means that taxpayers claiming the 45Y or 48E credits generally would not need to test payments made by their suppliers in determining whether those suppliers are FIEs for purposes of the taxpayer’s material assistance test. However, any suppliers claiming the section 45X credit must conduct their own FIE analysis, including applying the payments test with respect to their production of eligible components. for purposes of claiming the 45X tax credit. There are multiple ways to interpret the language in the statute, though, and the text could also be read to apply the payments test to suppliers in some cases.

Is there an exception from the material assistance rules for purchases of manufactured products and direct materials under an existing contract?

Yes. The material assistance provisions provide a limited “existing contract” exception. The exception excludes from the cost ratio the cost of any manufactured product, eligible component, or constituent element, material, or subcomponent of an eligible component that is acquired by/manufactured for the taxpayer pursuant to a binding written contract entered into before June 16, 2025. For sections 48E and 45Y, the facility that the materials are incorporated into must begin construction before August 1, 2025 and be placed in service before 2030 (except for wind and solar facilities, which must be placed in service before 2028). For 45X, the eligible component that the materials are used in must be sold before January 1, 2030.

4. Other changes to clean energy credits

In addition to the changes to the credit eligibility dates and the new foreign entity rules, the law makes a number of other policy changes. Below is a non-exhaustive list.

45Y/48E Clean Electricity Investment and Production Credits:

Domestic content bonus. The law raises the threshold percentages of domestic manufactured products required to claim the domestic content bonus for the section 48E ITC to generally match those for the section 45Y PTC. (The mismatch may have been unintended by the IRA.) This change does not apply to the section 48 ITC.

Domestic content/elective pay: Unlike prior versions of the Senate bill, the final legislation leaves in place the two exceptions from the requirement that projects of 1 MW or more must satisfy the domestic content rules to claim any credit. Those exceptions are for instances where domestic sourcing would raise construction costs by more than 25% or where relevant products are not sufficiently available.

Fuel cells: The law makes fuel cells eligible for the section 48E ITC, with a special exclusion from the zero-greenhouse gas emissions requirement that applies to other electricity-producing technologies. The fuel cell ITC rate is a flat 30%: there are no prevailing wage and apprenticeship rules or credit bonuses.

Lifecycle analysis: The law includes language directing the Secretary of the Treasury to “consider” studies that use “widely accepted lifecycle assessment concepts, such as concepts described in standards developed by the International Organization for Standardization.” This change does not require Treasury to take any new action that would expand eligibility for the credit. ​​

Leased property: The final legislation does not include a provision excluding residential solar installations that are leased or rented to homeowners from the section 48E credit. However, leased or rented solar water heaters and small wind property are made ineligible.

10% ITC: The final legislation terminates the provision that would have continued the ITC indefinitely at a 10% rate (or 2% without PWA).​​

45V Clean Hydrogen Production Credit: Under the final legislation, clean hydrogen facilities must begin construction before 2028, as opposed to 2033 under the IRA. The final bill does not apply foreign entity rules or make any other changes to the section 45V credit.

45Q Credit for Carbon Oxide Sequestration: The legislation raises the credit rates for captured carbon that is injected underground to extract oil or natural gas (“enhanced oil recovery”) or used in other ways (such as in a commercial product). For carbon capture equipment placed in service after enactment, those rates are raised from $60 per metric ton to $85 (assuming PWA rules are met), equaling the rate for CO2 that is captured and sequestered.

45X Advanced Manufacturing Production Credit:

Wind components: The legislation terminates the 45X credit for U.S. production of wind components (blades, nacelles, towers, etc.) after 2027.

Metallurgical coal: The law makes metallurgical coal eligible for the 45X credit through 2029 at a rate of 2.5% of production costs. The law does not restrict the use of such coal, with the result that the credit can now go to coal that is exported to foreign steelmakers, including those in China.

Integrated components: The law establishes additional requirements beginning in 2027 for taxpayers producing 45X-eligible components that are integrated into each other. If they wish to claim 45X credits for “primary components” that are integrated into “secondary components,” both components need to be produced in the same facility; 65% of the producer’s direct material costs for the secondary component must be for primary components mined, produced, or manufactured in the United States; and the secondary component must be sold to an unrelated third party.

45Z Clean Fuels Credit:

Two-year extension: The credit is extended from the end of 2027 to the end of 2029.

SAF rate: The legislation eliminates the higher rate for sustainable aviation fuel.

GHG determination:

ILUC: Under pre-OBBBA law, eligibility for the 45Z credit is restricted to fuels with a lifecycle GHG emissions rate below certain thresholds, with lower-emissions fuels receiving a higher credit. The emissions rate determination must take into account both direct and significant indirect emissions. However, OBBBA includes a new provision that specifically directs Treasury to ignore a major source of emissions — the indirect land use changes resulting from the use of crops as fuel feedstocks. This mandate will result in broader eligibility and higher credits for higher-emissions fuels.

Negative emissions rates: Under the legislation, emissions rates for fuels cannot be negative. That effectively caps the 45Z credit at $1 per gallon or gallon-equivalent (with inflation adjustments), with one significant exception, described below.

RNG from manures: Under current 45Z guidance, emissions rates for RNG from U.S. animal manures are determined based on average national manure types and management practices. The legislation directs Treasury to provide distinct emissions rates for fuels based on specific types of animal manure feedstock. Fuels derived from manures are specifically excluded from the prohibition on negative emissions rates. The upshot of these changes is that such fuels may become eligible for credits exceeding $1, depending on Treasury’s future emissions rate determinations, with no statutory upper limit.

Foreign feedstocks: The legislation limits eligibility for the 45Z credit to fuels exclusively services from feedstocks produced or grown in the United States, Mexico, or Canada.

Preventing double crediting: The legislation prevents double-crediting by providing that 45Z-eligible fuels cannot be produced from fuels that are themselves eligible for 45Z and by terminating the former sustainable aviation fuel excise tax credit.

Small agri-biodiesel credit: The legislation provides a 20-cent per gallon additional credit for agri-biodiesel with a per-producer cap through 2026 and makes the credit eligible for transferability.

45U Zero-Emission Nuclear Power Production Credit: The House-passed bill would have modified the termination date for 45U and earlier versions of the Senate bill would have imposed restrictions on sourcing nuclear fuel from covered nations. However, those provisions were dropped. The final bill’s only change to 45U is the addition of the foreign entity provisions described above.

title: Scientists Find New Way To Power Your Next Flight With Rotten Food - Jalopnik
description:
Scientists may have found a way to turn biocrude, a petroleum-like substance created from rotting organic matter, into sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), which can be used in place of polluting jet fuel.
It also provides a new pathway for producing SAF in the first place, which can power planes while lowering planet-killing emissions by 80%.
Either governments will need to subsidize SAF, or SAF will need to get cheaper.
The breakthrough these scientists have made doesn't necessarily solve those problems immediately, but it does open up another pathway to the production of SAF.
So if aviation wants to go green, the best way to do it is with SAF, which creates 80% fewer net emissions.
text:
Scientists may have found a way to turn biocrude, a petroleum-like substance created from rotting organic matter, into sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), which can be used in place of polluting jet fuel. This would be a major breakthrough if it pans out, since biocrude has had trouble finding a use case due to its high oxygen content versus fossil fuels. It also provides a new pathway for producing SAF in the first place, which can power planes while lowering planet-killing emissions by 80%. We're rooting for this one.

Research at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, with help from the Center for Advanced Bioenergy and Bioproducts Innovation, tested whether molybdenum carbide nanocatalysts, once dispersed onto the mineral zeolite, could remove oxygen from biocrude. They then upgraded the tar-like substance using hydrothermal liquefaction (HTL), a process that does in mere minutes what it takes the Earth eons to do — namely, turn dead biomass into explodey stuff that makes engines go vroom.

That all concluded with some very promising results, including complete oxygen removal and a high heating value (HHV) very near to the industry standard fuel, called Jet A. Getting rid of the oxygen is key, since the famously corrosive gas would eat through the actual plane engines, which would be very bad. In addition, this treated substance hit its targets in surface tension, density, freeze point, and other key metrics in order to qualify as SAF. While it's not quite ready to go into aircraft just yet, this is a huge step towards getting there.

There are already a number of ways to make SAF, and it can be made from a variety of sources (called feedstocks), including vegetable oils, fats, and greases. Did you flush your leftovers down the disposal last night? Should have put it in an airplane instead, it could have flown to Argentina with that.

Okay, not quite. But 360,000 commercial flights have already been powered by SAF, and Virgin Atlantic recently flew an entire flight with 100% SAF, so this is a proven technology that works. Plus, it just slots right into existing infrastructure; it can be piped through the same pipes and pumped into the same planes as ordinary fuel, so nothing needs to be re-engineered. It's a truly drop-in solution. The trick, as it ever is, is money. Right now, SAF is just more expensive than petroleum jet fuel, and given that fuel is one of an airline's highest costs, switching to it just isn't going to happen on its own. Either governments will need to subsidize SAF, or SAF will need to get cheaper. Plus, for the industry to switch over entirely, we're going to need to be able to make a lot more of the stuff.

The breakthrough these scientists have made doesn't necessarily solve those problems immediately, but it does open up another pathway to the production of SAF. The more we know about making the stuff, the likelier we'll find a cost-efficient solution. In this case, it also has the benefit of giving biocrude, which has otherwise struggled to find a use case, a new lease on life.

Air travel accounts for 2% of CO2 emissions globally, and fully 12% from the transportation sector, per the U.S. Department of Energy. Due to battery weight, electric planes for commercial use aren't plausible. So if aviation wants to go green, the best way to do it is with SAF, which creates 80% fewer net emissions. In other words, that banana peel rotting in your trash right now just might save the planet, if we can just find a way to turn it into jet fuel on the cheap.
